column2: These were known by their coats and pantaloons of black or brown, made to sit comfortably, with white cravats and waistcoats, broad solid-looking shoes, and thick hose or gaiters.--They had all slightly bald heads, from which the right ears, long used to pen-holding, had an odd habit of standing off on end.
column3: These were known by their coats and pantaloons of black or brown, made to sit comfortably, with white cravats and waistcoats, broad solid looking shoes, and thick hose or gaiters.--They had all slightly bald heads, from which the right ears, long used to pen holding, had an odd habit of standing off on end.

column2: Theirs was the affectation of respectability;--if indeed there be an affectation so honorable.
column3: Theirs was the affectation of respectability;--if indeed there be an affectation so honorable.

column2: The gamblers, of whom I descried not a few, were still more easily recognisable.
column3: The gamblers, of whom I descried not a few, were still more easily recognisable.

column2: Still all were distinguished by a certain sodden swarthiness of complexion, a filmy dimness of eye, and pallor and compression of lip.
column3: Still all were distinguished by a certain sodden swarthiness of complexion, a filmy dimness of eye, and pallor and compression of lip.

column2: They seem to prey upon the public in two battalions--that of the dandies and that of the military men.
column3: They seem to prey upon the public in two battalions-that of the dandies and that of the military men.

column2: Of the first grade the leading features are long locks and smiles; of the second frogged coats and frowns.
column3: Of the first grade the leading features are long locks and smiles; of the second frogged coats and frowns.

column2: All was dark yet splendid--as that ebony to which has been likened the style of Tertullian.
column3: All was dark yet splendid-as that ebony to which has been likened the style of Tertullian.

column2: I well remember that my first thought, upon beholding it, was that Retzch, had he viewed it, would have greatly preferred it to his own pictural incarnations of the fiend.
column3: I well remember that my first thought, upon beholding it, was that Retzch, had he viewed it, would have greatly preferred it to his own pictural incarnations of the fiend.

column2: I felt singularly aroused, startled, fascinated.
column3: I felt singularly aroused, startled, fascinated.

column2: How wild a history, I said to myself, "is written within that bosom!" Then came a craving desire to keep the man in view--to know more of him.
column3: How wild a history, I said to myself, "is written within that bosom!" Then came a craving desire to keep the man in view-to know more of him.

column2: Hurriedly putting on an overcoat, and seizing my hat and cane, I made my way into the street, and pushed through the crowd in the direction which I had seen him take; for he had already disappeared. With some little difficulty I at length came within sight of him, approached, and followed him closely, yet cautiously, so as not to attract his attention.
column3: Hurriedly putting on an overcoat, and seizing my hat and cane, I made my way into the street, and pushed through the crowd in the direction which I had seen him take; for he had already disappeared. With some little difficulty I at length came within sight of him, approached, and followed him closely, yet cautiously, so as not to attract his attention.

column2: I had now a good opportunity of examining his person.
column3: I had now a good opportunity of examining his person.

column2: He was short in stature, very thin, and apparently very feeble.
column3: He was short in stature, very thin, and apparently very feeble.

column2: It was now fully night-fall, and a thick humid fog hung over the city, soon ending in a settled and heavy rain.
column3: It was now fully night fall, and a thick humid fog hung over the city, soon ending in a settled and heavy rain.

column2: For half an hour the old man held his way with difficulty along the great thoroughfare; and I here walked close at his elbow through fear of losing sight of him.
column3: For half an hour the old man held his way with difficulty along the great thoroughfare; and I here walked close at his elbow through fear of losing sight of him.

column2: By and bye he passed into a cross street, which, although densely filled with people, was not quite so much thronged as the main one he had quitted.
column3: By and bye he passed into a cross street, which, although densely filled with people, was not quite so much thronged as the main one he had quitted.

column2: Here a change in his demeanor became evident.
column3: Here a change in his demeanor became evident.

column2: A second turn brought us into a square, brilliantly lighted, and overflowing with life.
column3: A second turn brought us into a square, brilliantly lighted, and overflowing with life.

column2: He urged his way steadily and perseveringly.
column3: He urged his way steadily and perseveringly.

column2: The rain fell fast; the air grew cool; and the people were retiring to their homes.
column3: The rain fell fast; the air grew cool; and the people were retiring to their homes.

column2: At no moment did he see that I watched him.
column3: At no moment did he see that I watched him.

column2: It was the most noisome quarter of London, where every thing wore the worst impress of the most deplorable poverty, and of the most desperate crime.
column3: It was the most noisome quarter of London, where every thing wore the worst impress of the most deplorable poverty, and of the most desperate crime.

column2: By the dim light of an accidental lamp, tall, antique, worm-eaten, wooden tenements were seen tottering to their fall, in directions so many and capricious that scarce the semblance of a passage was discernible between them. The paving-stones lay at random, displaced from their beds by the rankly-growing grass.
column3: By the dim light of an accidental lamp, tall, antique, worm eaten, wooden tenements were seen tottering to their fall, in directions so many and capricious that scarce the semblance of a passage was discernible between them. The paving stones lay at random, displaced from their beds by the rankly growing grass.

column2: Horrible filth festered in the dammed-up gutters. The whole atmosphere teemed with desolation.
column3: Horrible filth festered in the dammed up gutters. The whole atmosphere teemed with desolation.

column2: Yet, as we proceeded, the sounds of human life revived by sure degrees, and at length large bands of the most abandoned of a London populace were seen reeling to and fro. The spirits of the old man again flickered up, as a lamp which is near its death hour.
column3: Yet, as we proceeded, the sounds of human life revived by sure degrees, and at length large bands of the most abandoned of a London populace were seen reeling to and fro. The spirits of the old man again flickered up, as a lamp which is near its death hour.

column2: Once more he strode onward with elastic tread.
column3: Once more he strode onward with elastic tread.

column2: Long and swiftly he fled, while I followed him in the wildest amazement, resolute not to abandon a scrutiny in which I now felt an interest all-absorbing.
column3: Long and swiftly he fled, while I followed him in the wildest amazement, resolute not to abandon a scrutiny in which I now felt an interest all absorbing.

column2: He refuses to be alone.
column3: He refuses to be alone.
